title.narrative: Labs programme 2021-2025

description.narrative: Launched in 2019, the Life and Building Safety (LABS) Initiative is a collaborative effort to drive the apparel and footwear industry towards safer working conditions at the members’ brands’ suppliers, with the intention to embed best practices into local legislation and protocols. LABS is a separate legal entity, where IDH act as the program secretariat, convening a strong coalition of global brands, key industry stakeholders, and decision-makers, including the private sector, governments, and civil society, to unlock resources and work towards preventing and mitigating fire, electrical, and structural risks in the apparel and footwear industry.

title.narrative: Number of multi-stakeholder agreements signed as a result of IDH interventions

description.narrative:
Number of multi-stakeholder agreements signed as a result of IDH interventions. A multi-stakeholder agreement is a collection of institutional arrangements, decision-making processes, policy instruments, and underlying values in the system by which multiple actors pursue their interests in sustainable food and manufacturing, ecosystem service conservation, and livelihood security. These institutional arrangements include multi-stakeholder platforms and coalitions that represent the main actors in the sector and landscapes responsible for sustainable production, landscape governance and planning.
Typical activities through which IDH seeks to influence sector or landscape governance including supporting the development of policy frameworks – such as Green Growth Plans and Sector Initiatives – including the convening of the multi-stakeholder platforms and coalitions required for these; influencing policy changes or supporting improved enforcement; attracting and mobilizing investments for sustainability solutions; and capacity building of local government.

title.narrative: Number of new or improved policies or standards that are effectively enforced

description.narrative: The total number of new policies (including laws and regulations) launched by governments to enhance sustainable development related to IDH programs + the total number of improved policies (including laws and regulations) that were amended to enhance sustainable development related to IDH programs + total number of voluntary standards that were either created or amended to enhance sustainable business practices in IDH sectors.

title.narrative: Number of multi-stakeholder coalitions, committees, secretariats, initiatives, and platforms convened to sign and support a common vision, goals, or strategy on sustainable development or sourcing

description.narrative: A multi-stakeholder coalition is a partnership of various stakeholders from the private sector, public sector, civil society, and/or worker/producer representatives or organizations representing the main interests of different stakeholder groups in defined sector, landscape or compact area. This coalition is often referred to as a “platform” or “partnership”. They are mainly convened and work at sector, landscape or compact scales. Multi-stakeholder platforms at the market level are convened at the national (India, China) or multinational level (EU).

title.narrative: Number of targeted market actors that adopted or updated their sourcing, procurement policies or strategies to include sound social and environmental sustainability criteria and goals

description.narrative:
The total number of market actors that have adopted new or updated their existing sourcing/procurement policies or strategies to include sound and credible social and environmental sustainability criteria or goals.
“Targeted” means that the market actor in question has been identified by the Market’s Program as a priority to help adopt or update their sourcing or procurement policies.
“Sound and credible social and environmental sustainability criteria or goals” must be assessed according to existing and operational (international) standards and certification schemes supported by IDH Programs.

title.narrative: Number of diagnostic analysis finalized

description.narrative: The number of data driven approaches, diagnostic or assessments performed by IDH. This might include diagnostic assessments, data driven approaches, “gap analysis”, Service Delivery Model (SDM) analysis, working conditions, Salary Matrix, or any types of evidence-based consultancy services given by IDH programs to private sector partners to co-develop business cases or assess performances on social, environmental and financial outcomes. An analysis is considered finalized when the report has been published online or privately distributed between companies and IDH.

title.narrative: Number of factories, cooperatives, SMEs, plantations, traders reached with technical assistance (non-financial assistance)

description.narrative: This indicator measures the unique number of Value Chain Actors with access to selected categories of technical assistance. Technical assistance refers to non-financial assistance provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, instruction, skills training, transmission of working knowledge, and consulting services and may also involve the transfer of technical data or improved processes co-financed by IDH.

title.narrative: Other sources of public, private or blended-finance investments/funding leveraged by the program

description.narrative:
The total value of all direct and indirect public, private, and blended-finance investments/funding (in euros) committed by (impact) investment funds, donor organizations, and government institutions to support IDH project activities in sustainable commodity production and natural resource protection. These include but not limited to the co-funded projects within IDH program but also result of IDH’s convening work or co-funding of preparatory or capacity building (de-risking) work.
Direct funding refers to co-funding contributed by non-private parties in IDH projects. Indirect funding refers to leveraged funding that is not captured in contracts but is a result of IDH’s work.

title.narrative: Number of workers with improved working conditions

description.narrative: Measurement of the unique number of workers who are employed by target factory or plantation which are supported through IDH interventions. Working conditions are considered improved when one or more of the following conditions are improved due to IDH intervention: 1. Number of workers gained affiliation to unions or relevant workers’ representation bodies 2. Number of workers gained coverage by Collective Bargain Agreements 3. Number of workers benefit from newly established grievance procedure mechanisms 4. Number of workers gained safer working conditions via a building safety assessment and/or new access to Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) 5. Number of workers benefit from reduction of issues (incidents, accidents, grievance, gender-based violence cases/sexual harassment cases) raised by workers
